MATH5315M: Applied probability & statistics - HTML Version of module Lecture Notes

The aim of this module is to learn the most important concepts in probability theory and statistics, and to introduce and develop a number of methods in statistics usually used in applied financial analysis. On completion of the module, you will be expected to be able to communicate the theoretical and applied concepts of probability and statistics, and to carry out statistical tests and interpret the findings. The material can be split into three sections: fundamentals of probability and statistics, simple statistical analyses and time series methods.

The notes in this document are not exhaustive and should be supplemented with additional information from both the lectures and the recommended reading. Each chapter of the notes has been linked with chapters from the recommended reading to help with this. Throughout the notes there are examples that will be discussed in the lectures, and you will be expected to take notes covering the examples. Additional examples not in these notes will also be explained in the lectures.

In the notes, the mention of the implementation of the techniques in a computer-based statistical package has been kept to a minimum. However, you must bear in mind that we will be investigating how we can run these analyses on specific datasets. In the second half of the module, some of our focus will be on implementation in a statistical package called R. We use R because it

  • â€¢ is rich enough to handle all the techniques we cover in this module
  • â€¢ can be used to do more advanced analyses that you will be facing later in the programme
  • â€¢ is free and available on many operating systems, and
  • â€¢ is versatile enough for new methods to be easily created (which might be important in your future careers).

1 Data Summaries - (CT3 Unit 1)

Data exist in many different forms, and we need to understand the differences to perform useful statistical analyses. Often, simple statistical summaries and well-made graphs can remove the need for complicated (and sometimes expensive) analysis.

1.1 Types of Data

Batch data are a set of related observations.
Sample data are a set of observations that are chosen to be representative of some population.

Numerical (quantitative) - Discrete {0,1,2,3,â€¦}â¢orâ¢{12,1,2,4}

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â    Â  Â  Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Nominal (e.g. colour) - â€œno orderâ€
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â    Â  Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Ordinal (e.g. agree, disagree, donâ€™t careâ€¦)

We can also make numerical (rather than graphical) summaries of a dataset.

For a set of n observations, x1,x2,â€¦,xn, the mean is defined by:

xÂ¯=1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nxi.

The median is the â€˜middleâ€™ observation in a data set which has been sorted. If n is odd, it is the n+12th observation. If n is even, it is the mid point between n2thâ¢andâ¢n+22th observation.

The mode of a dataset is the value that occurs most frequently.

The mean, median and mode are all measures of location.

The range is the difference between the largest and smallest values in a data set:

R=maxğ‘–â¢(xi)-minğ‘–â¢(xi).

The interquartile range is the difference between the upper and lower quartiles: IQR = UQ - LQ, where the lower quartile is the 25â¢tâ¢h percentile, and the upper quartile is the 75â¢tâ¢h precentile (see below).

A box plot is a useful visualisation tool that shows the LQ, IQR and UQ.

Percentiles extend the idea of quartiles. For example, the 5th percentile is the value such that 5% of the data falls below it. The nearest rank method for calculating the rank at which the Pth-percentile will occur uses the formula:

n=âŒˆP100Ã—NâŒ‰

where N is the total number of observations. We equate the nth observation with the Pth-percentile.

There are other methods like linear interpolation

and the sample standard deviation is:

Most of the data falls in (xÂ¯-3â¢s,xÂ¯+3â¢s).

The range, IQR, variance and standard deviation are all measures of spread.

2.4 Theorem of total probability

Example 9

= 0.8Ã—0.50.8Ã—0.5+0.5Ã—0.5=0.62â¢Â (to 2 d.p.).

3.7 Moments (CT3 Units 1 and 3)

Moments are calculated from datasets or probability distributions for random variables. They give us a way of describing the key features of data or random variables. We have covered much of this already focussing on two of the moments and using a different notation. It is worth revisiting these looking from the perspective of moments because they give us an alternative way to describe both data and random variables.

3.7.1 Moments for a dataset (sample moments)

The mean and variance are special cases of the moments of a dataset. In general, the ktâ¢h order moment about a value Î± is defined by:

mkâ¢(Î±)=1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1n(xi-Î±)k

If k=1, and Î±=0, then mkâ¢(Î±)=xÂ¯,

and the variance s2=nn-1â¢m2â¢(xÂ¯).

So, mk is the ktâ¢h moment about the sample mean and mkâ€² is the ktâ¢h raw moment (i.e. about zero).

The first four moments are related to the following:
m1 - location,
m2 - spread,
m3 - skewness,
m4 - kurtosis.

A measure for skewness is given by:

g1=m3m23/2â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€†(coefficient of skewness)

The sign of g1 gives the direction of the skew.

3.9 Functions of random variables (continuous)

If we have a random variable X and a function (with unique inverse) defined for all values of X, u(.), then we can consider the properties of Y=uâ¢(X) (we have already considered a transformationâ€™s impacts on expectation earlier).

FYâ¢(y) = P(Yâ‰¤y) is what we are interested in and we can recover fY(y) by differentiation of FY(y).

x=w(y)=u-1(y).â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€‚â€ƒ(*)

If u(x) is an increasing function, then

= P(X<w(y))=FX(w(y)),

fYâ¢(y) = dâ¢FXâ¢(wâ¢(y))dâ¢y
= dâ¢FXâ¢(z)dâ¢zâ¢dâ¢wâ¢(y)dâ¢yâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ[using chain rule]

We know FXâ¢(x) and y=uâ¢(x) has a unique inverse as given in (*). If uâ¢(x) is a decreasing function, then

FYâ¢(y) = P(u(x)<y)=P(X>w(y))
= 1-FXâ¢(wâ¢(y)),

= -fXâ¢(wâ¢(y))â¢dâ¢wâ¢(y)dâ¢y.

because the derivative of a increasing function will be positive and the derivative of a decreasing function will be negative.

4.5 Poisson

Xâˆ¼ Po(Î»)

Number of independent events in a specified time interval.

This distribution models the number of events in a specified time interval, when events occur one after another in a well-defined manner. 6 Generating Functions (CT3 Unit 5)

6.1 Probability generating functions - Discrete

Let X be a counting variable which take values 0,1,2,3,â€¦ (i.e., xâˆˆâ„•âˆª{0}) with probabilities p0,p1,p2,p3,â€¦ respectively. We define the probability generating function (PGF) as

GXâ¢(t) = Eâ¢[tX]
= p0+p1â¢t+p2â¢t2+â€¦

Thus, pk equals the coefficient of tk in GX(t). It is easy to see that GXâ¢(1)=1 and GXâ¢(0) = P(X=0). GXâ¢(t) exists at least for |t|â‰¤1. This gives us an alternative mechanism for describing the distribution of a discrete random variable.

Also, if X and Y have the same probability generating function, then they have the same distribution.

6.2 Evaluating moments using PGFs

The PGF, GXâ¢(t), can be used relatively easily to find low-order moments.

If we differentiate GXâ¢(t) with respect to t and set t=1, we end up with Eâ¢[X]:

Eâ¢[X]=dâ¢GXâ¢(t)dâ¢t|t=1.

Further differentiation yields higher order moments. Recall Varâ¢(X)=Eâ¢[X2]-{Eâ¢[X]}2, and, using PGFs, we have

Eâ¢[X2]=d2â¢GXâ¢(t)dâ¢t2|t=1+dâ¢GXâ¢(t)dâ¢t|t=1.

7 Joint Distribution (CT3 Unit 6)

Defining several random variables on a sample space gives rise to a multivariate distribution. If you have two random variables, then you have a bivariate distribution.

7.1 Notation and properties

The function fX,Y(x,y) = P(X=x,Y=y), defined for all possible values of x and y, is the joint probability function.

To have a joint probability function for two (discrete) random variables, we require

fX,Yâ¢(x,y)â‰¥0â€ƒâ€ƒâ€†(every probability is positive),
âˆ‘xâˆ‘yfX,Yâ¢(x,y)=1â€ƒâ€ƒâ€†(all probabilities add up to 1).

In the case of a pair of continuous variables, we have a function fX,Y(x,y) defined over the x,y - plane, called the joint probability density function.

The probability of X,Y taking values in some region is given by:

P(x1<X<x2,y1<Y<y2)=âˆ«y1y2âˆ«x1x2f(x,y)dxdy

We are integrating the area under a surface defined by z=fâ¢(x,y) so we need to look at double integration.

The joint distribution function is defined by

F(x,y)=P(X<x,Y<y),

and it is related to the density function through

âˆ‚2â¡FX,Yâ¢(x,y)âˆ‚â¡xâ¢âˆ‚â¡y=fX,Yâ¢(x,y).

To qualify as a joint probability density function, we must have that

fX,Yâ¢(x,y)â‰¥0,âˆ€x,y,
âˆ«-âˆâˆâˆ«-âˆâˆfX,Yâ¢(x,y)â¢ğ‘‘xâ¢ğ‘‘y=1.

7.4 Independence of Random Variables

Consider a pair of random variables (X,Y) and suppose that Y does not actually depend on X at all. It follows that the conditional distribution of Y|X, fâ¢(y|x), is simply the marginal distribution of Y, fYâ¢(y). So,

fYâ¢(y) = fâ¢(y|x)=fX,Yâ¢(x,y)fXâ¢(x)

fX,Yâ¢(x,y)=fXâ¢(x)â¢fYâ¢(y).

7.6 Covariance and Correlation Coefficient

The covariance between X and Y is defined as:

Covâ¢(X,Y) = Eâ¢[(X-Eâ¢[X])â¢(Y-Eâ¢[Y])]
= Eâ¢[Xâ¢Y]-Eâ¢[X]â¢Eâ¢[Y].
Note that Covâ¢(X,X) = Eâ¢[(X-Eâ¢[X])â¢(X-Eâ¢[X])]
= Eâ¢[(X-Eâ¢[X])2]
= Varâ¢(X).

ÏX,Y is the correlation coefficient such that ÏX,Y=Covâ¢(X,Y)(Varâ¢(X)â¢Varâ¢(Y)).

This is a quantity between -1 and 1. The closer |ÏX,Y| is to 1 the stronger the linear relationship. If ÏX,Y = 0, we say that X and Y are uncorrelated, and they have no linear relationship.

If X and Y are independent, then,

ÏX,Y=0.

If ÏX,Y = 0, however, X and Y may still be dependent.

10.3 Unbiasedness

If we have a random sample X = {X1,â€¦â¢Xn} from a distribution with unknown parameter Î¸ and g(XÂ¯) is an estimator for Î¸, we want

If an estimator is biased the bias is measured by E[g(XÂ¯)]-Î¸. This property is not preserved under non-linear transformations of the estimator and parameter.

11 Confidence Intervals (CT3 Unit 10)

A confidence interval provides an â€˜interval estimateâ€™ of an unknown parameter (instead of just a â€˜point estimateâ€™). Therefore, we get some appreciation of the accuracy of the estimate.

A 100â¢(1-Î±)% confidence interval for Î¸ is defined by specifying random variables Î¸^1â¢(XÂ¯) and Î¸^2â¢(XÂ¯) such that:

Pr(Î¸^1(XÂ¯)<Î¸<Î¸^2(XÂ¯))=1-Î±,

which gives the confidence interval:

(Î¸^1â¢(XÂ¯),Î¸^2â¢(XÂ¯)).

There are infinitely many choices for the random variables given Î±, so confidence intervals are not unique. The usual choice for Î± is Î±=0.05 so we will have a 95% confidence interval. In the long run, if we repeated the experiment that yielded XÂ¯ and we calculate a 95% interval in the same manner, 95% of such intervals will contain Î¸.

â‡’ Pr(XÂ¯-1.96Ïƒn<Î¼<XÂ¯+1.96Ïƒn)=0.95
Figure of a normal curve, confidence interval shaded

If we look at the width of the interval, the larger n is (i.e., the more data we have), the more confidence we have in the estimate.

12 Hypothesis Testing (CT3 Unit 11)

A hypothesis is a proposed possible explanation for a set of circumstances. For example, we might hypothesise that the mean value for some population is some specified value.

The basic hypothesis being tested is the null hypothesis (H0). In a hypothesis test, we contrast this with the alternative hypothesis (H1).
For example, H0:Î¼=0 vs. H1:Î¼â‰ 0.

A test is a rule that divides the space of possible experimental results into two regions. In one region, the results are consistent with H0. In the other, they are not (this second region is the critical region).

The test answers the question â€˜Do the data provide sufficient evidence to justify rejecting H0?â€™. For the test, we need to find a suitable test statistic for which we can define a distribution under the null hypothesis.
Â 
The level of significance of the test, Î±, is the probability of committing a type I error; that is, rejecting H0 when H0 is true.
Â 
The probability of committing a type II error is Î². This is the probability of not rejecting H0 when it is false. (1-Î²) is called the power of the test.
Â 
An ideal test would minimise both Î± and Î². In practice, this is difficult so we often fix Î± and pick a test that minimises Î².

12.1 Single Sample Tests for Means

We have a sample from Nâ¢(Î¼,Ïƒ2), and we would like to know if it is reasonable to say Î¼=Î¼0.
So we have:

H0:Î¼=Î¼0â¢Â vs.Â â¢H1: Î¼â‰ Î¼0 two-sided
Î¼>Î¼0,Î¼<Î¼0 one-sided

If Ïƒ2 is known, our test statistic is:

Z=XÂ¯-Î¼0Ïƒ/nâˆ¼Nâ¢(0,1)â¢Â underÂ â¢H0,Â orÂ â¢Xâˆ¼Nâ¢(Î¼0,Ïƒ2).

If Ïƒ2 is unknown, our test statistic is:

T=XÂ¯-Î¼0s/nâˆ¼tn-1,Â underÂ â¢H0.

12.2 P-Value

We can also assess the strength of the rejection of H0 using the p-value.
The p-value is the probability of seeing a test statistic as extreme as the one in our experiment under the assumptions of H0.

12.2.1 What the p-value is not

  • â€¢

    It is not the probability that H0 is true (or false).

  • â€¢

    It is not the probability of getting the value of the test statistic.

Example 65
\hdashlineLet Xiâˆ¼i.i.d.Nâ¢(Î¼,3) and xÂ¯={-1,1,2}, so xÂ¯=23. (a) H0:Î¼=0â¢Â vs.Â â¢H1:Î¼â‰ 0 Then to find the p-value: pâ¢-value = Pr(|XÂ¯|>23|H0), = Pr(XÂ¯<-23|H0)+Pr(XÂ¯>23|H0), = 0.2525+(1-0.7475), = 0.5050. So, under the null hypothesis, a value this extreme for the test statistic is not that unlikely. (b) H0:Î¼=-1â¢Â vs.Â â¢H1:Î¼>-1 Then to find the p-value: pâ¢-value = Pr(XÂ¯>23|H0), = 0.0478. Hence, the p-value<0.05. So we can reject H0 at the 5% level, but, as p-value>0.01, we cannot reject H0 at the 1% level. \hdashline

12.6 Contingency Tables

Draw a 2-way contingency table (maybe use example 70)

A contingency table is a two-way table of counts obtained when sample observations are classified according to two categorical variables. In this case, the null hypothesis is:

Â Â Â Â Â vs.
H1: the two classification criteria have some dependence.

The test statistic is essentially a comparison between observed values in the table and values that we would expect to get if the criteria were independent. Expected value of cell in table =(row totalÂ Ã—Â column total)table total.

13 Correlation and Regression (CT3 Unit 12)

We use correlation to measure the strength of linear relationships between two variables. This is closely related to the problem of fitting a straight line through some data points. The process of fitting a straight line is called linear regression.
In linear regression, we use a straight line to describe the relationship between y, the response (or dependent) variable, and x, the explanatory (or independent) variable.

13.2 The Simple Linear Model

Given a set of n pairs of data (xi,yi),i=1,â€¦,n; the yi are regarded as a response random variable Yi given xi. For the purpose of this type of analysis, the xi, the values of the explanatory variable, are regarded as constants.
The simple linear model is the following relationship:

Yi=Î±+Î²â¢xi+ei,i=1,â€¦,n,

where the ei are uncorrelated with mean 0 and have common variance Ïƒ2; i.e., Eâ¢(ei)=0, Varâ¢(ei)=Ïƒ2 and Covâ¢(ei,ej)=0,âˆ€iâ‰ j. Note that:

Eâ¢[Yi|xi] = Eâ¢[Î±+Î²â¢xi+ei]
= Eâ¢[Î±]+Eâ¢[Î²â¢xi]+Eâ¢[ei]
= Î±+Î²â¢xi.

Here, Î² is the slope parameter and Î± is the intercept. To fit the model, we must estimate Î±,Î² and Ïƒ2. The fitted regression line (or fitted model) that we can use to estimate Y given x is given by

y^=Î±^+Î²^â¢x,

where

Î²^=Sxâ¢ySxâ¢x

and

Î±^=yÂ¯-Î²^â¢xÂ¯.

These estimates come from minimising the sum of squared errors for the regression model (exercise).

We want to find Î± and Î² such that âˆ‘i=1n(y^i-yi)2 is minimised. Letâ€™s set
hâ¢(Î±,Î²) = âˆ‘i=1n[(Î±+Î²â¢xi)-yi]2,
âˆ‚â¡hâ¢(Î±,Î²)âˆ‚â¡Î± = âˆ‘i=1n2â¢(Î±+Î²â¢xi-yi),
set this to zero:Â â¢âˆ‘i=1nyi = nâ¢Î±^+Î²^â¢âˆ‘i=1nxi
âŸ¹Î±^ = yÂ¯-Î²^â¢xÂ¯.
âˆ‚â¡hâ¢(Î±,Î²)âˆ‚â¡Î² = âˆ‘i=1n2â¢xiâ¢(Î±+Î²â¢xi-yi),
set to zero & sub inÂ Î±^:Â â¢âˆ‘i=1nxiâ¢yi-yÂ¯â¢âˆ‘i=1nxi = Î²^â¢(âˆ‘i=1nxi2-xÂ¯â¢âˆ‘i=1nxi)
âŸ¹Î²^ = Sxâ¢y/Sxâ¢x.
We could also perform the second partial derivative test to check it is a minimum.
Powerpoint slides: Correlation and regression.pptx

The estimate for the error variance is:

Ïƒ^2=1n-2â¢âˆ‘i=1n(yi-y^i)2=1n-2â¢âˆ‘ri2,

where ri=(yi-y^i) are the residuals from the fitted model.

Warning: Lookout for outliers as they can give regression line leverage and skew data.

We also have that Î²^ is the observed value of a statistic B^, whose sampling distribution has the properties:

Eâ¢(B^) = Î²,
Varâ¢(B^) = Ïƒ2Sxâ¢x.

To help understand the â€˜goodness of fitâ€™ of our model to the data, we investigate the total variation in the response, which is Syâ¢y=âˆ‘(yi-yÂ¯)2.
In particular, we want to know how much of the variation can be explained by our model as opposed to random variables. We look at departures from predicted responses:

yi-yÂ¯ = (yi-y^i)+(y^i-yÂ¯),
which gives,
(yi-yÂ¯)2 = [(yi-y^i)+(y^i-yÂ¯)]2,

and, using âˆ‘i=1n(yi-y^i)=0, we can get:

Syâ¢y=âˆ‘(yi-yÂ¯)2= âˆ‘(yi-y^i)2+âˆ‘(y^i-yÂ¯)2.
i.e.,
Total sum of squares= Residual sum of squares+Regression sum of squares

Note: This is sometimes written as SST=SSR+SSE, or TSS=RSS+ERR.

SST = sum of squares in total, SSR = sum of squares explained by the regression, SSE = sum of squares for the errors. TSS = total sum of squares, RSS = regression sum of squares, ERR = error sum of squares

We will use SSTOT=SSRES+SSREG. For computation,

SSTOT= Syâ¢y
SSREG= âˆ‘i=1n[(Î±^+Î²^â¢xi)-(Î±^+Î²^â¢xÂ¯)]2=Sxâ¢y2Sxâ¢x
SSRES= Syâ¢y-Sxâ¢y2Sxâ¢x

For this model, the level of correlation between X and Y is highly related to the goodness of fit. The proportion of the total variability in y is explained by the linear model and is called the coefficient of determination,

R2=SSREGSSTOT=Sxâ¢y2Sxâ¢xâ¢Syâ¢y.

Note that:

  • â€¢

    If R=1, the model provides a perfect fit,

  • â€¢

    If R=0, the model is doing nothing,

  • â€¢

    For a linear model, R2 is the square of the correlation coefficient.

13.3 The Normal Linear Model

13.5 Multiple Linear Regression

An extension of the simple linear model is made by allowing for multiple explanatory variables:

Yi=Î±+Î²1â¢xiâ¢1+Î²2â¢xiâ¢2+â€¦+Î²kâ¢xiâ¢k+ei,i=1,â€¦,n.

We end up with very similar sampling distributions that enable us to test if Î²i=0 or not. We can also use the same sum of squares partition to get the population of variance explained by the model.

14 ANalysis Of VAriance (ANOVA) (CT3 Unit 13)

A â€˜one-way analysis of varianceâ€™ (or one-way ANOVA) is used to compare k â€˜treatmentsâ€™ when an experiment provides ni responses for treatment i, i=1,â€¦,k. The data are then n(=âˆ‘ini) responses yiâ¢j, where yiâ¢j is the jtâ¢h observation for the itâ¢h treatment. â€˜Treatmentâ€™ for us could mean company, country, employment status, etc..

Î¼=1nâ¢âˆ‘iâˆ‘jEâ¢[Yiâ¢j]

and Ï„i is the difference made on average by treatment i.
Estimation of the parameters follows a least-squares maximisation procedure:

Î¼^ = YÂ¯âˆ™âˆ™â¢whereâ¢YÂ¯âˆ™âˆ™=1nâ¢âˆ‘iâˆ‘jYiâ¢j
Ï„^i = YÂ¯iâ£âˆ™-YÂ¯âˆ™âˆ™â¢whereâ¢YÂ¯iâ£âˆ™=1niâ¢âˆ‘j=1nYiâ¢j.
Also,â€ƒâ€‚Ïƒ^2 = 1n-kâ¢âˆ‘iâˆ‘j(Yiâ¢j-YÂ¯iâ£âˆ™)2
and 1Ïƒ2â¢âˆ‘iâˆ‘j(Yiâ¢j-YÂ¯iâ£âˆ™)2âˆ¼Ï‡n-k2.

Again, we partition the variability:

âˆ‘iâˆ‘j(Yiâ¢j-YÂ¯âˆ™âˆ™)2 = âˆ‘iâˆ‘j(Yiâ¢j-YÂ¯iâ£âˆ™)2+âˆ‘iniâ¢(YÂ¯iâ£âˆ™-YÂ¯âˆ™âˆ™)2.
(SSTOT = Â â€ƒâ€‚â€ƒSSRESâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€‚â€ƒ+â€ƒâ€ƒâ€‚SSTRE)

vs.

15 Assessing Model Fit Numerically

When we have several competing models, there are many metrics available to help us decide which model is â€˜bestâ€™. If we are simply interested in how well a model fits data, we may consider the root mean squared-errors (RMSE):

MSE = 1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1n(y^i-yi)2,
RMSE = MSE.

We might be interested in finding the model with smallest RMSE. In general, the more variables/parameters that we add to our model, the lower the RMSE, regardless of whether the variables are related or if the extra parameters explain the variation (this is called overfitting).

Diagram demonstrating overfitting

15.1 Information Criteria

The Akaike information criterion (AIC) provides a way of judging models that takes into account the number of parameters being used as well as the fit. We use the following formula:

AIC=2â¢k-2â¢lnâ¢(l*),

where k is the number of parameters and l* is the maximised likelihood for the fitted model.

Again, we want to minimise AIC. AIC is smaller for simpler models (small k) and for models with larger maximum likelihood.
There is another metric that penalises for the number of parameters even more: the Baysian Information Criterion (BIC):

BIC=lnâ¢(n)â¢k-2â¢lnâ¢(l*).

where n is the number of observations. (If n>8, BIC will be larger than AIC.) We try to find the model with the smallest BIC.

Example 77
\hdashlineFit three different models to 50 observations. Model No. of parameters l* RMSE AIC BIC 1 3 8.28 0.4821 1.77 9.58 2 6 14.16 0.4511 6.70 18.7 3 100 18.31 0.0026 194.19 385.39 From this table, we can see we penalise the model where we use 100 parameters. In this example, there are 50 observations and 100 parameters: we should not use this model. \hdashline

15.2 Cross-validation

An alternative approach to avoiding over-fittingâ€” and to make comparisons between models â€” which does not inherently favour a specific model assumption, is to use cross-validation.

The main idea is to split the n observations into two complementary sets: a training or learning set, say LâŠ‚{1,â€¦,n} and a test set, say T={1,â€¦,n}âˆ©Lc. Any model or procedure is then fit to the data in L, but then models are compared using the data in T. To give an example, a regression model (which could be nonparametric) could be fit to observations (xi,yi),iâˆˆL and then the model could be used to predict y for each xi,iâˆˆT, giving y^i,iâˆˆT. Then comparisons can be made by considering

âˆ‘{i,iâˆˆT}(yi-y^i)2.

Such an approach can be used for selecting smoothing parameters, by successively choosing T={1},T={2},â€¦,T={n} and this is known as â€œleave-one-out cross-validationâ€.

For the purposes of model or method comparisons it would be common to choose the size of L to be approximately n/2, with observations selected at random from the original set. When forecasting is the objective (as in the next chapter) it would then be more natural to take the test set T to be the latest observations available.

16 Time Series (Brooks Ch 5)

A time series is a set of variables (or data) that are indexed by some notion of time.
Â 
Examples:

  • â€¢

    Daily close price for some stock,

  • â€¢

    Monthly interest rates for some national bank (time refers to month),

  • â€¢

    Stock price after trades (time is ordering or trades).

A time series model is a model that uses past time series observations to provide a mechanism to predict future values; for example, using historical stock data to predict future prices. The time series models we will be looking at will not contain any external explanatory variables. Our models are just based on past observations (this is called an empirical approach to modelling).

16.1 Notation and Important Concepts

Our time series are sequences of random variables:

â€¦,X0,X1,X2,â€¦â¢Â orÂ â¢â€¦,Y0,Y1,Y2,â€¦,

or, once they have been observed, sequences of data values:

x0,x1,x2,â€¦,xnâ¢Â orÂ â¢y0,y1,y2,â€¦â¢yn.

We also have the concept of lag. There is a lag of 1 between x1 and x2, a lag of 2 between x5 and x7, etc.. In general, there is a lag of s between xk and xk+s.

A strictly stationary process is a time series where for any time indices and integer k,

FYt1,Yt2,â€¦â¢Ytrâ¢(y1,â€¦,yr)=FYt1+k,Yt2+k,â€¦â¢Ytr+kâ¢(y1,â€¦,yr)

That is, the joint distribution of the variables making up the time series does not change over time.
A weakly stationary process is a time series such that:

Eâ¢[Yt] = Î¼,âˆ€t,
Varâ¢(Yt) = Ïƒ2<âˆ,âˆ€t,
Covâ¢(Yt1,Yt2) = Î³t2-t1,âˆ€t1,t2.

The autocovariance between two time points t2>t1 is

Î³t2-t1=Covâ¢(Yt1,Yt2).

The autocorrelation at lag s is given by

Ï„s=Î³s/Î³0

if we have a weakly stationary process.
Â 
â€œAuto-â€ comes from the Greek for self.

The partial autocorrelation at lag s, denoted by Î±s, is the autocorrelation between Yt and Yt+s with the linear dependence of Yt+1 to Yt+s-1 removed. It can also be thought of as the autocorrelation between Yt and Yt+s that is not accounted for by the autocorrelation at lags 1 to s-1.

Think about a perfect linear relationship between two neighbouring variables in a time series. What does this mean for autocorrelation and partial autocorrelation?

There are three main plots that we will consider when analysing time series:

  1. 1.

    Data value vs. time

  2. 2.

    Autocorrelation vs. lag

  3. 3.

    Partial autocorrelation vs. lag

All of these can be used to help select a time series model.

The model is:

where GÎµ is any distribution (t,â„±,â€¦) that satisfies some properties that are given below. Note that ÏƒÎµ2 is the only parameter. We have Gaussian white noise if GÎµâ¢(0,ÏƒÎµ2)=Nâ¢(0,ÏƒÎµ2).

White noise processes have the following properties:

  1. 1.

    Eâ¢(Xt)=0,âˆ€t,

  2. 2.

    Varâ¢(Xt)=ÏƒÎµ2,âˆ€t,

  3. 3.

    Covâ¢(Xt,Xt+k)=0,âˆ€t,kâ‰ 0.

16.6 Identifying which model to use

We could use the acf(.) and pacf(.) plots to help identify models to fit.
For an AR(p) model:

acf: magnitude decreases geometrically,
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pacf: no significant partial autocorrelation after lag p.

For a MA(q) model:

acf: no significant autocorrelation after lag q,
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pacf: magnitude decreases geometrically.

For a ARMA(p,q):

acf: like acf for AR model after first few lags,
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pacf: like pacf for MA model after first few lags.

We can also use model selection criteria, AIC and BIC, to help select our model.

16.7 Model Checking

Choosing a good model for a set of data is not always easy, so it is important to compare models (for example using AIC), and then to check that the residuals from a fitted model form a white noise process. This can be checked by plotting the residuals, plotting an acf of the residuals, and using the Box-Pierce or Ljung-Box â€œportmanteauâ€ tests, for which the test statistics are given by

Q=nâ¢âˆ‘k=1KÏ^k2

and

Q=nâ¢(n+2)â¢âˆ‘k=1K(n-k)-1â¢Ï^k2

respectively. Here, K is a user-chosen number to reflect the number of lags which are to be considered, and the statistic is compared to a Ï‡2 distribution with K-p-q degrees of freedom.

16.8 Forecasting with Time Series Models

Often, we will want to ask: what value do we expect our time series to take several steps ahead? One way to think about this is to work out what the expectation and variance for the time series are several steps ahead. If we do it this way, then we have a point estimate and some appreciation of its accuracy.

16.9 Lag Operator

The i-step lag operator (sometimes called the â€œbackshiftâ€ operator), Bi, is defined by Biâ¢Xt=Xt-i.
We can define our AR(p) model in terms of this operator:

Xt=c+(âˆ‘i=1pÏ•iâ¢Bi)â¢Xt+Îµt,
(1-âˆ‘i=1pÏ•iâ¢Bi)â¢Xt=c+Îµt.

This helps us define the next type of model using first differences:

X1-X0,X2-X1,X3-X2,â€¦
(1-B)â¢Xt=Xt-Xt-1.
This gives us another way of writing previous models. For example, the AR(1) model can be written as
(1-Ï•â¢B)â¢Xt=c+Îµt.

where c,Î¸1,â€¦,Î¸q,ÏƒÎµ2,Ï•1,â€¦,Ï•p are model parameters.
All of our models so far are contained in this model:

ARâ¢(p) â‡” ARIMAâ¢(p,0,0),
MAâ¢(q) â‡” ARIMAâ¢(0,0,q),
ARMAâ¢(p,q) â‡” ARIMAâ¢(p,0,q).
â€œIntegratedâ€ comes from the the definition that a time series is integrated of order 0 if it admits a moving average representation with âˆ‘_k=0^âˆâˆ£Î¸_k^2âˆ£Â¡ âˆ, where Î¸ is the possibly infinite vector of moving average weights. This implies that the autocovariance is decaying to 0 sufficiently quickly. This is a necessary, but not sufficient condition for a stationary process. Therefore, all stationary processes are Iâ¢(0), but not all Iâ¢(0) processes are stationary.

16.11 Vector Autoregressive Models

A vector autoregressive model with parameter p, VAR(p) is:

X1,t = c1+âˆ‘i=1pÏ•1,1,iâ¢X1,t-i+â€¦+âˆ‘i=1pÏ•1,n,iâ¢Xn,t-i+Îµ1,t,
â‹®
Xn,t = cn+âˆ‘i=1pÏ•n,1,iâ¢X1,t-i+â€¦+âˆ‘i=1pÏ•n,n,iâ¢Xn,t-i+Îµn,t.

where all Îµi,jâˆ¼i.i.d.GÎµâ¢(0,ÏƒÎµ2).

Actually, this error structure is a simplified version of the full VAR model which has a covariance matrix to model dependence in the errors across the time series.

Suppose we have n time series:

1sâ¢tâ¢Â time series: â€¦,X1,0,X1,1,X1,2,â€¦
2nâ¢dâ¢Â time series: â€¦,X2,0,X2,1,X2,2,â€¦
â‹®
ntâ¢hâ¢Â time series: â€¦,Xn,0,Xn,1,Xn,2,â€¦

We could model {X1,t} using an AR(p) process:

X1,t=c1+âˆ‘i=1pÏ•1,1,iâ¢X1,t-i+Îµ1,t

We could model {Xr,t} using a separate AR(p) process:

Xr,t=cr+âˆ‘i=1pÏ•r,r,iâ¢Xr,t-i+Îµr,t

What if we thought that X1,t depended on both its previous values and previous values from other time series? We could write:

X1,t=c1+âˆ‘i=1pÏ•1,1,iâ¢X1,t-i+âˆ‘i=1pÏ•1,2,iâ¢X2,t-i+â€¦+âˆ‘i=1pÏ•1,n,iâ¢Xn,t-i+Îµ1,t.

We could then do this for all n time series simultaneously, and this is a VAR(p) model. Each time series is a constant plus a linear combination of its p previous values, and the p previous values from the other time series, plus error.

Remember: For Ï•r,s,i, r is the index for the time series that you are modelling, s is the index of the time series that you are considering past values for and i is the number of â€˜steps backâ€™ that we are considering.

17.2 Returns and (Crude) Volatility

Note that there are several definitions for both of these

We have an observed time series:

x0,x1,â€¦,xn.

We can create another time series by looking at differences at lag 1 (in R, use ğšğš’ğšğšâ¢(â€¦)).

x1-x0,x2-x1,â€¦,xn-xn-1

In finance, we are often interested in a rescaled version of this given by the series of arithmetic returns:

r1,r2,â€¦,rn,whereâ¢rt=xt-xt-1xt-1.

Example 82 \hdashlineThe price at close of BP stock was 417.0 and 423.1 over two consecutive days (6.1 gain). For G4S, the prices at the same time were 241.7 and 246.2 (4.5 gain). Return for BP: 423.1-417.0417.0 =0.0146 Return for G4S: 246.2-241.7241.7 =0.0186 \hdashline

Because the arithmetic return can change by orders of magnitude from day to day, the logarithmic returns are usually reported.

lâ¢r1,lâ¢r2,â€¦,lâ¢rn,Â whereÂ â¢lâ¢rt=lnâ¢(xt)-lnâ¢(xt-1)=lnâ¢(xtxt-1).

One measure of volatility of a time series over n time steps is:

âˆ‘i=1n(lâ¢ri-lâ¢rÂ¯)2(n-1)â€ƒâ€ƒâ€†(the sample variance for log returns).

If the variance of our time series is fixed over time, this volatility measure should be fixed over time. In a time series based on stock prices, we often see changes in volatility over time, and high volatility occurs in bursts. Further, low volatility over a period will (on average) lead to more low volatility, and high volatility will (on average) lead to more high volatility. This suggests correlation in volatility over time.

If variability is unchanged over time, we say that the time series model is homoscedastic. If variability changes over time, we say the time series model is heteroscedastic.

17.3 Autoregressive Conditional Heteroscedastic (ARCH) Model

An ARCH model is essentially two models: one for the mean behaviour and one for the variance. The typical set-up is to have an ARMA(p,q) for the mean behaviour and a separate model for the variance based on variances from previous time steps.

Recall that ARMA(p,q) is

Xt=c+Îµt+âˆ‘i=1pÏ•iâ¢Xt-i+âˆ‘i=1qÎ¸iâ¢Îµt-i

with independent Îµt|Ïƒt2âˆ¼GÎµâ¢(0,Ïƒt2). Now,

ARCHâ¢(q*): Ïƒt2= Î±0+âˆ‘i=1q*Î±iâ¢Î½t-i2,
Î½t= Ïƒtâ¢zt,
where ztâˆ¼i.i.d. Gzâ¢(0,1).

The parameters for this model are the ARMA parameters, plus Î±0,Î±1,â€¦,Î±q* and Ïƒz2.
Î±0 is the expected variance over the time series;
Î±1,â€¦,Î±q* tell us how related the current variance is to variances at previous timesteps;
Ïƒz2 tells us how far Ïƒt2 could move in time.
Essentially, the bigger the Î±i, the more volatile the time series, and the bigger Ïƒz2, the more heteroscedastic the time series.

Example 83 \hdashline The ARCH(1) model is given by Ïƒt2 = Î±0+Î±1â¢Î½t-12 Î½t2 = Ïƒt2â¢zt2=(Î±0+Î±1â¢Î½t-12)â¢zt2 with Varâ¢[zt]=1 and Eâ¢[zt]=0. This is a bit like ar AR(1) process but in Î½t2 rather than Î½t, and with multiplicative noise with a mean of 1, rather than additive noise with a mean of zero. We have Eâ¢[Î½t2âˆ£Î½t,â€¦] = Eâ¢{(Î±0+Î±1â¢Î½t-12)â¢zt2âˆ£Î½t-1,Î½t-2,â€¦} = Î±0+Î±1â¢Î½t-12â¢Eâ¢(zt2âˆ£Î½t-1,Î½t-2,â€¦) = Î±0+Î±1â¢Î½t-12 If Î½t-1 has a large (absolute) value, the Ïƒt is larger than usual, and so Î½t is also expected to have an unusually large magnitude. This volatility propagates since when Î½t has large deviation, then Ïƒt+12 is large and so on. Similarly for small values. So, unusually large volatility in Î½t tends to persist, though not forever. \hdashline

17.4 Generalised Autoregressive Conditional Heteroscedastic (GARCH) Model

This is the same as ARCH, but with a MA process as well as the AR process for Ïƒt2.

The GARCH(p*,q*) model is thus defined by

Î½t = Ïƒtâ¢zt,
Ïƒt2 = Ï‰+âˆ‘i=1p*Î±iâ¢Î½t-12+âˆ‘j=1q*Î²jâ¢Ïƒk-j2,

where Ï‰>0,Î±iâ‰¥0,Î²jâ‰¥0, and the innovation sequence zt is i.i.d.Â with Eâ¢[zt]=0 and Varâ¢[zt]=1.
